I feel like the guys who came up with this are trolling us. Name the elements in latin (and then half the way down change to english with latin suffixes for no good reason), use greek prefixes to indicate number, then use arabic numerals as subscripts and superscripts. This is science, not the Da Vinci code. Pretty sure if the astronomers can demote Pluto then chemists can come up with a less scattered nomenclature.

You're welcome and Thank You!

Chloride ions (Cl) have a -1 charge.  So two of them would have a total charge of -2 which is why Cu had a +2 charge in CuCl2.  In CuSO4 we have a polyatomic ion, sulfate, which has a -2 charge.  Now we only have 1 sulfate ion (SO4^2-), so Cu has a +2 charge to balance. Hope this helps!
